triples.name: Free will
triples.relevance: The central philosophical concept that both books debate, exploring whether humans have the capacity to make uncaused choices independent of physical determinism.

triples.name: Evolution
triples.relevance: Mitchell's key argument that free will could have emerged through evolutionary processes that produced biological organisms.

triples.name: Natural selection
triples.relevance: Discussed as the mechanism by which organisms pack knowledge about their environment into their physical structure, serving as a foundation for decision-making.

triples.name: Neuroscience
triples.relevance: The scientific discipline invoked to understand how the nervous system and brain contribute to the mechanisms underlying free will and agency.

triples.name: Quantum mechanics
triples.relevance: Mitchell relies on interpretations of quantum physics developed by Smolin and Verde to argue that the future is genuinely open and not fully determined by current physical states.

triples.name: Consciousness
triples.relevance: Discussed as a distinct ontological category related to sentience that the reviewer argues may be necessary to properly explain free will alongside lower-level biological processes.

triples.name: Moral responsibility
triples.relevance: Central theme of the debate, questioning whether and to what extent free will is necessary for holding individuals morally responsible for their actions.

triples.name: Determinism
triples.relevance: Sapolsky's core claim that determinism is true and incompatible with free will, forming the basis for his denial of moral responsibility.

triples.name: Genetics
triples.relevance: Mitchell's field of study, relevant to the discussion of how hereditary traits and genetic information influence organism behavior and decision-making.
